image.altText: A group of swimmers doing a nude solstice dip.

props.synopsis: Thousands of people celebrate the shortest day of the year by taking a nude plunge in the freezing waters of Hobart.

title.children: Around 3,000 swimmers go nude for an 'energising' winter solstice dip in Hobart

image.altText: an edited photo showing man in an orange search jacket and a woman with long blond hair, with forest in the background

props.synopsis: It's been two years since tourist Celine Cremer disappeared without a trace in a Tasmanian rainforest, but high-profile private investigator Ken Gamble is certain she is within a 1km radius of where her phone last "pinged".

title.children: Phone data may hold answers on Belgian woman missing in Tasmania

image.altText: A white man with white hair and reading glasses in a smart-casual suit.

props.synopsis: With the state of the budget being a major trigger for Tasmania's snap poll, experts are urging both major parties to outline their savings plans and get spending under control.

title.children: 'Show us their savings': Business leader, economist on Tasmanian election

image.altText: Steph Cameron pushing her son Bruce on a swing.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian Liberals have pledged to make it easier for Tasmanians and their children to access attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) diagnosis and treatment.

title.children: GPs will be able to diagnose and treat ADHD, pledge Tasmanian Liberals

image.altText: multiple firearms laid out on the ground.

props.synopsis: A George Town man is charged with multiple offences, including firearm possession, after officers observed "items of interest" through the window of a home.Â

title.children: Police find 'imitation' gun stash while looking through man's window

image.altText: Metro bus

props.synopsis: Tasmania's government-owned bus company has instructed drivers to hide their coin trays while within a major bus mall in Hobart after a series of thefts, while a union says the government has reneged on a promise to increase security on buses.

title.children: Metro drivers told to hide money when within Glenorchy bus mall

image.altText: Stateline Tasmania interviews Richard Eccleston

props.synopsis: ABC Stateline's Guy Stayner speaks with Tasmanian political analyst Professor Richard Eccleston.

title.children: No indication major parties can improve Tasmanian budget, Richard Eccleston says

image.altText: Three Collingwood players come together to celebrate a goal.

props.synopsis: Collingwood has won coming off the bye, overcoming a willing challenge from St Kilda at Docklands to extend their lead at the top to a game and a half.

title.children: Magpies extends lead on AFL ladder, Carlton coach 'disappointed in the whole team'

image.altText: Ryan Papenhuyzen of the Storm celebrates after kicking a field goal

props.synopsis: Ryan Papenhuyzen kicks the match-winning field goal in golden point to sink the Rabbitohs, despite four tries from Alex Johnston.

title.children: Storm survive in golden point on day of NRL upsets, as Johnston's four tries creates history

image.altText: A man in a suit looking at the camera and pointing with his palm.

props.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says that in his view the whole of Ukraine is "ours" and cautions that advancing Russian forces could take the Ukrainian city of Sumy as part of a bid to carve out a buffer zone.

title.children: Putin explains belief that 'the whole of Ukraine is ours'

image.altText: A composite of the Meta and Google logos.

props.synopsis: Billions of login credentials have been leaked and compiled into datasets online, giving criminals "unprecedented access" to accounts, according to new research.Â

title.children: Billions of logins for sites such as Google and Facebook leaked online

props.synopsis: As bombs fall on Tehran, Iranians speak of their fear and confusion about the situation now and what will come next.Â

title.children: From chaos to empty streets, inside Iran as the conflict with Israel escalates

image.altText: A group of swimmers doing a nude solstice dip.

props.synopsis: Thousands of people have celebrated the shortest day of the year by taking a nude plunge in the freezing waters of Hobart.

title.children: Around 3,000 swimmers go nude for an 'energising' winter solstice dip in Hobart

image.altText: dark clouds hover over perth cbd

props.synopsis: Three cold fronts will generate damaging winds, heavy rain, isolated thunderstorms and pockets of small hail across southern states.

title.children: Major winter storm to bring gales, rain and snow to southern Australia

image.altText: A man is speaking to media after releasing from detention centre

props.synopsis: Mr Khalil's release marks a major victory for rights groups that challenged what they called the Trump administration's unlawful targeting of a pro-Palestinian activist.

title.children: Mahmoud Khalil freed from immigration custody after US judge's ruling

image.altText: a picture of a bbay looking straight at the camera

props.synopsis: Two boys, aged 14 and 15, have been charged with assault occasioning bodily harm and wilful damage after allegedly spraying a baby with a fire extinguisher.

title.children: E-bike riders charged over fire extinguisher incident that injured baby

image.altText: Villawood Immigration Detention Centre

props.synopsis: A man dies in hospital days after he was allegedly attacked by a former immigration detainee freed under a landmark High Court ruling.

title.children: Melbourne man dies after alleged assault by released immigration detainee

image.altText: Tech start-up founder Julian Fayed with new staff member Tien Hung Nguyen.

props.synopsis: While overall employment is holding up, there are increasing signs that artificial intelligence is eating away at opportunities in some parts of the job market, especially for entry-level white-collar work.

title.children: 'This is going to be very, very disruptive': Employers issue warning on AI

image.altText: A group of seven cars line up to cross the finish line together on a red claypan at Lake Perkolilli.

props.synopsis: A father and son with a mutual love of vintage cars have spent the past three years restoring a 1928 Model A Ford as one of Australia's oldest motor racing events, the Red Dust Revival, prepares to roar back to life.

title.children: Vintage car for race a 'labour of love' for father and son

image.altText: Banners are held by pro-assisted dying campaigners in London

props.synopsis: The "Terminally Ill Adults (End of Life)" law would give mentally competent, terminally ill adults in England and Wales with six months or less left to live the right to choose to end their lives with medical help.

title.children: UK parliament votes for assisted dying, paving way for historic law change

image.altText: Land clearing NSW

props.synopsis: Investigations are under way into satellite images the Australian Conservation Foundation says are proof farmers across Australia have illegally cleared 900 square kilometres of native habitat in five years.

title.children: Conservation group compiles 'shocking' evidence of mass habitat loss

image.altText: A heater on the floor with two feet warming up next to it. The feet have socks on

props.synopsis: Tourists are stunned to discover they were warmer back in a country that's blanketed by snow for months of the year.

title.children: Even visitors from snowy countries realise Australian winters feel too cold

image.altText: A woman sleeps with a quilt on against a blue backdrop

props.synopsis: Felt like staying in bed longer this morning? It might be because the shorter days are affecting your circadian rhythm.

title.children: It's the shortest day of the year. Here's how that might be affecting your sleep

image.altText: A person stands on the deck of a ship holding a white balloon in the air there is a large ice block and water in the background.

props.synopsis: Scientists are venturing to the Southern Ocean to study clouds and the world's cleanest air to better understand climate change and the impact of human activity on the Earth's atmosphere.

title.children: Pristine Antarctic clouds hold clues to climate model blind spots

image.altText: Minjee Lee holds a golf ball as she walks off the green during the Women's PGA Championship.

props.synopsis: Hannah Green's eagle on the 14th hole was almost certainly the shot of the second round at the Women's PGA Championship, while Minjee Lee stayed in touch with the red-hot leader.

title.children: Green holes shot of the day as fellow Aussie Lee stays in major mix

image.altText: A newborn baby is shown lying down, with one of its feet in the foreground of the image.

props.synopsis: Queensland police have finalised their investigation into a Brisbane couple's international surrogacy case with no charges laid. Surrogacy advocates say the case shows Australia's are outdated.

title.children: Couple who allegedly used overseas surrogate for baby won't be charged

image.altText: A collection of beanies displayed on a wall.

props.synopsis: An intricate hot air balloon beanie and a woolly hat made entirely from dog fur are among the almost 7,000 creations on display at this year's Alice Springs Beanie Festival.

title.children: In the outback, 7,000 beanies â including one made of dog fur â are stealing the show

image.altText: Karratha gas plant

props.synopsis: Shared revenue from Australia's largest mainland gas project has dropped by more than 70 per cent in three years, contributing less than 1 per cent of the state's revenue this financial year.

title.children: Budget reveals WA oil and gas royalties in rapid decline

image.altText: Jim Chalmers responds to ABC Leaders Debate, federal election 20

props.synopsis: There was no mistaking the impression that the treasurer is emboldened by the election result and wants to seize his moment.

title.children: Jim Chalmers wants to pick a fight on tax â and time is of the essence

image.altText: Worker with a takeaway coffee cup next to their computer

props.synopsis: The Queensland beachside town of Noosa has voted to phase out disposable coffee cups despite the council lacking the power to enforce a ban.

title.children: Noosa on a green mission to ban single-use coffee cups

image.altText: A large piece of equipment on the port.

props.synopsis: The founder of two major new marine infrastructure projects in Western Australia is weighing up a bid for the Darwin Port.

title.children: Australian business considering bid for embattled Darwin Port

image.altText: A woman wearing a long-sleeved blue shirt standing in a storage container of clothing.

props.synopsis: As the nation tackles a cost-of-living crisis, community heroes like Roylene Robinson are supporting others struggling to make ends meet.

title.children: Foster mum who raised 280 kids now helps people with cost of living

image.altText: England bowler Ben Stokes leans forward and grimaces during a Test against India.

props.synopsis: England captain Ben Stokes sends India in to bat on day one of the first Test, only to watch the tourists' new generation combine to plunder centuries.

title.children: England rues 'staggering' decision to bowl first in Test against India

image.altText: Archival photo underground miners Mount Isa

props.synopsis: It's almost impossible to picture this outback mining city without its stacks, but that could be the future.Â

title.children: As Australia's deepest copper mine calls time, what happens to Mount Isa?
